title: Fall 2024 EdTech Policy Academy for Africa
description_long:
The Fall 2024 EdTech Policy Academy for Africa offers an immersive,  learning experience aimed at enhancing education policy frameworks with a focus on digital transformation. Participants will join peers from across Africa to analyze existing EdTech policies, learn from real-world case studies, and develop actionable roadmaps for implementation.

The course begins with an introductory module where you get to meet your colleagues and share insights about your country’s educational challenges. In Week 1, “Discover,” a series of expert panel discussions guide you through the core pillars of EdTech policy—from digital infrastructure and connectivity to digital skills, system management, and envisioning future-ready schools.

You’ll engage in daily reflection activities to identify challenges and possible solutions inspired by global and regional best practices, including the integration of artificial intelligence in education. Week 2, “Develop,” focuses on transforming insights into action as you craft a tailored Roadmap to Action, culminating in a powerful message to leadership on the strategic priorities for your country. In the final week, “Share,” you will present your roadmap to a wider community, exchange feedback with peers, and refine your strategy, paving the way for certification upon successful course completion. This comprehensive program not only equips you with the tools to overcome current challenges but also inspires innovative thinking to drive inclusive and effective digital education reforms.

lessons.title: Lesson 1 : Welcome to the United Republics of Learning
lessons.video_transcript:
Welcome to the United Republics of Learning

Greetings, team! We are very excited to be together for the next few weeks as part of the new EdTech Policy Academy for Africa, where innovation meets education. As you know, my name is Bob Hawkins, and I am your Minister of Education at the United Republic of Learning.

Our challenge at the ministry is clear: we need to foster cross-country collaboration, implement effective EdTech strategies, and explore the transformative role of new technologies such as AI. We must stay abreast of these technologies and be able to leverage them to improve teaching and learning in our classrooms. Our objectives for the ministry and our participation in this academy include tracking progress and sharing lessons learned among participants through engaging panel discussions.

We need to build upon the great work you‚Äôve all done and ensure that everyone in our ministry is aware of it. We also need to update action plans and implement EdTech strategies with a focus on resource allocation and prioritization, because plans without action are meaningless. Lastly, we will be exploring the role of AI and other emerging trends in education, as we need to continuously innovate as a ministry.

The academy in which we will all participate will last for three weeks, with an estimated commitment of 10 to 15 hours per week. I hope all of you will be fully engaged so that we can make the most of our time together. In week one, we will come together in panel discussions on various EdTech topics inspired by the EdTech Readiness Index developed by the World Bank, as well as discuss essential elements of our vision and policy to create a resilient hybrid learning system in the United Republic of Learning. Topics will include devices and connectivity, digital skills, digital resources, system management, implementation capacity, and our vision for the School of the Future‚Äîwith AI as a crosscutting theme.

In week two, country teams from across the United Republic of Learning will participate in individual meetings with instructors to work on revising or drafting their EdTech policy strategies and action plans. These sessions will focus on actionable solutions tailored to each of your needs.

Finally, in week three, we‚Äôll conclude with final presentations, sharing our knowledge across the Ministry of the United Republic of Learning, where each country team will showcase their learnings and outline next steps. These presentations will be held in both English and French to accommodate all of our colleagues across the ministry.

Our engagement in the academy will be delivered online, combining synchronous and asynchronous activities on our course platform to ensure flexibility and accessibility for all participants. We want to model how our learners might experience hybrid learning themselves.

Remember, in the United Republic of Learning, we are all teachers, but most importantly, we are all learners.

I‚Äôm very excited about your participation in this journey to transform education through technology. Together, I truly believe we can shape the future of learning in Africa and transform our ministry at the United Republic of Learning.

Thank you very much, and I look forward to seeing you soon.

Introduction:

The EdTech Policy Academy provides capacity building experiences and "just-in-time" support to country teams engaged in the design and implementation of EdTech components within current and upcoming projects.

By the end of this course, you will:

  • Analyze or update EdTech policies while learning from the experiences of other countries in Africa.
  • Develop a Roadmap to Action to implement EdTech strategies (including resource availability and prioritization at different educational levels).
  • Explore the role of artificial intelligence and other upcoming trends in education.

What the Course Offers:

As a participant, you will have access to a diverse range of resources curated by the World Bank EdTech Team. You will also examine case studies from countries worldwide allowing you to extract valuable lessons learned. The portfolio will offer you a dedicated space for exchanging knowledge and sharing reflections with fellow participants. 
 
Upon successful completion of the course, you will receive a certification. To qualify for certification, you need to post at least one reflection each week in the portfolio.


What We Request From You:

The estimated‚ÄØlearning time required to complete the course is 10-15 hours spanning across 3 weeks. However, depending on your availability and review of additional resources, you may choose to extend your commitment. Participants are advised to allocate between 3 to 5 hours each week.

Final Presentation - Transcription
Good afternoon, Africa. Good afternoon, United Republic of Learning. My name is Changal. I
am part of the World Bank EdTech team, and welcome to your final presentation, which is
somewhat like a graduation ceremony for the 2024 EdTech Policy Academy for Africa.
This session, as you can see from the screen, has two segments. The first is about five
countries that worked on teacher skills, teacher technology, and leveraging technology for
teacher training. These five countries will be speaking in English. After each segment, there will
be feedback provided by the adviser of the minister. For the first segment, it will be Barbara,
and in the second segment, it will be Fred. After each expert review or feedback, we will have
a 20-minute Q&A session.
While you listen to the interviews between the vice minister and the country or provincial
representatives within our United Republic of Learning, please post your questions in the chat.
We will document them and, during the Q&A, send them over to the minister. This way, she
can call on you. If you have any questions, feel free to put them in the chat.
Another thing: we have collected all your PowerPoints. However, because we have so many
countries participating in the current Policy Academy, we won‚Äôt be using PowerPoints. Instead,
it will be a conversation between the country representative and the vice minister. We have
hosted all your PowerPoints in a Google Drive. Sarah, Alex, and I will be pasting those in the
chat. If you want to learn more about a specific country intervention, please click on those, and
you‚Äôll be able to view the content.
With this in mind, let‚Äôs move on to our United Republic of Learning. I‚Äôm going to hand it over
to our Minister Bob. Over to you, Minister Bob.
Minister Bob:
Good afternoon, colleagues. Thank you very much for coming to this All-Hands Ministry
meeting today. It has been an exciting three weeks, and thank you for rising to the challenge of
the demands we‚Äôve received from our president to develop action plans to ensure our policy
can be implemented.
I‚Äôm very excited to see all of the briefing notes you have prepared for this meeting. As Changal
said, we will be sharing these among all participants. I want this to be an active discussion
around the key topics raised by our colleagues from across the United Republic of Learning.
Please add questions to the chat, participate, and interrogate the ideas presented.
If we can record this session, that would be fantastic. Changal and I would also like to take a
picture at the end of this session. Please stay online so we can capture everyone with their
faces visible.
Remember our five principles:
1. Always ask why.
2. What is the change you want to see in the classroom?
3. How do we reach all of our students at scale for all?
4. How do we empower teachers?
5. How do we use data more effectively?
 Final Presentation - Transcription
Today‚Äôs discussion about teachers is critical. At the end of the day, this is a change
management process, and teachers are at the frontline of this change. I‚Äôm very excited to hear
what you have to say about the role of teachers and how we can empower them to make
changes in the classroom.
Unfortunately, I have some bad news. I have been called to a budget meeting by the president.
I will be listening in but must now pass this chair over to our Vice Minister Karen to manage
this session. Rest assured, I will be advocating for resources to execute our action plan. With
that, let me pass this over to our Vice Minister. Thank you, colleagues.
Vice Minister Karen:
Thank you very much, Minister Bob, for handing over. I understand that attending a budget
meeting with the president is extremely important, especially as it relates to financial
discussions critical to our plans for the United Republic of Learning.
Today, we have the pleasure of listening to various countries. Let‚Äôs start immediately with
Nigeria. Mustafa, are you with us?
Nigeria - Mustafa:
Hi Karen, good afternoon. I‚Äôm doing well. Greetings from Nigeria‚Äîit is 2:11 PM here.
Vice Minister Karen:
Thank you, Mustafa. Excellent. Let‚Äôs dive straight in. The minister and I have reviewed your
plan to leverage EdTech in teacher training for both primary and secondary education. It is
comprehensive, well-drafted, and includes strong points. We‚Äôd like to hear more about how
you plan to incentivize teachers for their professional development. What incentives will you
provide? Let‚Äôs start with that.
Mustafa:
Thank you, Karen, and everyone. To begin, I‚Äôd like to inform you about the Nigeria National
Teachers Institute, which has the constitutional mandate for continuous professional
development of teachers. With the focus now on ICT and EdTech, we believe these tools will
not only enhance teachers' ICT capacity but also positively impact lesson delivery and overall
student outcomes.
One of the key ways to incentivize teachers is by formalizing certification. Many teachers worry
that beyond gaining knowledge, they won‚Äôt receive recognition within the system. Teachers
value promotions and salary improvements as incentives. Formalizing certification could
ensure their efforts lead to recognition and career advancement, even for those with only a
first degree.
Vice Minister Karen:
Absolutely, Mustafa. That makes sense. Do you believe the National Teachers Institute will be
sufficient to drive these initiatives, or will additional stakeholders be involved?
Mustafa:
EdTech is a global phenomenon and should be given the right recognition. To ensure
sustainability, we need to review and expand our current systems. Piloting will be critical.
Through pilot programs, we can identify challenges related to infrastructure, policy
environment, manpower, and alignment with existing curricula.
 Final Presentation - Transcription
We already have an institution responsible for teacher development. We simply need to
amplify the integration of EdTech into the system. By selecting communities, schools, and
teachers for the pilot, we can assess the 360-degree impact of EdTech and refine our
approach.
Vice Minister Karen:
That sounds ambitious but doable. How do you see stakeholders collaborating to integrate
both digital literacy and pedagogical skills into the education system?
Mustafa:
From experience, stakeholder engagement is crucial. Existing bodies like quality assurance
teams already conduct school monitoring and lesson observations. It‚Äôs about involving them in
the EdTech conversation and building on their institutional memory.
For example, organizations such as the Nigerian Computer Society, the Education Management
Information System (EMIS), and others involved in ICT policy can contribute valuable insights.
Aligning their expertise with our long-term vision for primary and secondary education is vital.
We must also establish benchmarks for students. For instance, by the end of secondary school,
students should have foundational skills in web design, AI, and robotics. This ensures that even
if students don‚Äôt proceed to university, they have practical ICT skills for the workforce.
Vice Minister Karen:
Thank you, Mustafa. Your focus on incentivization and piloting is inspiring. Let‚Äôs move on to
Kenya. Dominic and Martin, are you with us?
Kenya - Dominic and Martin:
Yes, we are here.
Vice Minister Karen:
Wonderful. How are you today?
Dominic:
We are doing well, thank you.
Vice Minister Karen:
Great. We were impressed by your progress in equipping teachers with basic digital literacy
skills. Could you elaborate on what you mean by basic skills and how you plan to build on your
success to help teachers integrate these with pedagogical skills?
Dominic:
Basic ICT skills refer to the ability to use digital devices, develop digital content, and leverage
online resources. Initially, there was a misconception that teachers needed programming or
coding expertise to use technology effectively. Our approach focuses on demonstrating that
technology can enhance teaching across all disciplines, from languages to sciences.
We target multiple stakeholders, including boards of management, parents, and school
administrators, to emphasize the importance of technology in learning. By gaining their
support, we can ensure investments in digital tools and teacher training.
 Final Presentation - Transcription
For teachers, we plan to use an online portal where they can access self-paced courses tailored
to their training needs. These courses will include simplified content and support via
communities of practice. We will issue certifications to those who complete the courses
successfully and provide ongoing monitoring and support.
Vice Minister Karen:
Thank you, Dominic. I appreciate your emphasis on stakeholder involvement and communities
of practice. How do you think teachers will react to self-paced learning with limited guidance?
Dominic:
We anticipate initial challenges, but we have learned from our pilot program involving 300
teachers. Based on their feedback, we simplified the content and developed offline options for
those with connectivity issues. We also assign trainers to support teachers via SMS and within
their communities of practice.
This phased approach, along with peer support, should help us overcome any challenges and
ensure teachers feel confident navigating the portal.
Vice Minister Karen:
Excellent. Thank you, Dominic and Martin. Let‚Äôs now hear from Uganda. Annette, are you with
us?
Uganda - Annette:
Yes, I am here.
Vice Minister Karen:
Good afternoon, Annette. How is Uganda this afternoon?
Annette:
Good afternoon, Karen. Uganda is doing well.
Vice Minister Karen:
Wonderful. I understand you aim to leverage technology to enhance both pre-service and inservice teacher training. Despite existing CPD programs, adoption of digital skills in classrooms
remains low. Why do you think this is, and how are you addressing it?
Annette:
Thank you, Minister. In Uganda, digital skills initiatives are often institution-based without a
unified national framework. Schools or universities implement their own programs, leading to
inconsistencies.
To address this, we‚Äôve developed a structured approach centered on three strategies. First, we
will map existing digital skills and resources across institutions. Second, we will prioritize
capacity-building initiatives for teachers. Finally, we aim to establish a national teacher
education ICT curriculum to provide clear guidelines for all institutions.
Vice Minister Karen:
Thank you, Annette. I like the idea of developing a national framework and harmonizing
initiatives. Could you elaborate on the role of your research team and how their findings will
be harmonized at the national level?
 Final Presentation - Transcription
Annette:
Certainly. Our research team will collect data from institutions to identify existing digital skills,
resources, and gaps. Once the data is analyzed, we will prioritize interventions based on the
findings.
For example, we will ensure teachers can use technology to conduct research, design engaging
content, and create learner-centered activities. With limited funding, we will focus on
impactful initiatives, such as training teachers to maximize available resources.
Our national digital strategy will guide these efforts, ensuring every institution follows a
structured approach to teacher development. This will help us prepare both teachers and
learners for the technology-driven future.
Vice Minister Karen:
Thank you, Annette. Your structured approach and emphasis on a national strategy are
commendable. Let‚Äôs now move to Tanzania. Alard and Lucian, are you here?
Tanzania - Alard and Lucian:
Yes, we are here.
Vice Minister Karen:
Great to have you with us. I understand that your focus is on improving blended learning
through CPD programs. You‚Äôve highlighted tools, content, data, and modalities. Additionally,
you emphasize communities of practice. Could you explain what communities of practice mean
in your context and how they support your objectives?
Alard:
Good afternoon, Karen, and everyone. Thank you for the opportunity.
We have developed an ACT Digital Education Strategy outlining CPD initiatives, including
leveraging communities of practice (CoPs). CoPs provide a dynamic platform for peer-driven
knowledge sharing, mentorship, and sustained professional growth.
For example, experienced teachers can mentor their peers within these communities, sharing
best practices, tools, and teaching methods. CoPs also foster ongoing engagement,
encouraging teachers to stay motivated and committed to their professional development.
Additionally, CoPs facilitate cross-disciplinary learning, enabling teachers from different
backgrounds to exchange ideas and innovate. This broadens their skillsets and enhances
blended learning approaches.
Vice Minister Karen:
How will you set up these communities of practice?
Alard:
In Tanzania, we have established "Hub Schools" as centers for collaboration. Teachers from
different schools come together at these hubs to share experiences and resources.
For example, teachers from Hub School A can share their approaches and tools with teachers
from Hub Schools B and C. We also use technology platforms like Zoom and Google Meet to
connect teachers virtually, enabling them to discuss challenges and solutions regularly.
 Final Presentation - Transcription
Lucian:
To add to Alard‚Äôs points, we also focus on co-creation within CoPs. Teachers collaborate to
develop open educational resources that can be shared widely. Feedback loops within these
communities ensure continuous improvement and alignment with our goals.
By leveraging existing technologies, we can connect teachers across regions, fostering a culture
of collaboration and lifelong learning.
Vice Minister Karen:
Thank you, Alard and Lucian. Your strategy for CoPs is impressive and well thought out. Let‚Äôs
move on to Liberia. Nataniel and San, are you with us?
Liberia - Nataniel and San:
Yes, we are here.
Vice Minister Karen:
Good afternoon. I understand that Liberia is working to transition traditionally-minded
teachers to a more digital approach. You‚Äôve mentioned infrastructure deficits, teacher training,
and resource availability as key challenges. Could you elaborate on how you are addressing
these challenges?
Nataniel:
Thank you, Karen. Yes, infrastructure deficits are a major challenge. Many schools lack reliable
internet access and modern technology. To address this, we have established digital labs in
156 public secondary schools. These labs are equipped with computers and other tools,
enabling students and teachers to access digital resources.
For teacher training, we recently trained 50 master trainers who will train 312 teachers in
these schools. This ensures that teachers have the confidence and skills to use digital tools
effectively.
Resource availability remains a challenge due to limited funding. However, we are engaging
partners like the Spec Foundation and the government to increase budget allocations for
EdTech.
San:
Another challenge is resistance to change. Many teachers are accustomed to traditional
methods and view digital platforms as a threat. To address this, we‚Äôve conducted community
engagements to demonstrate how digital tools can complement their work rather than replace
it.
We are also aligning our national curriculum with digital tools. Teachers with ICT content
knowledge are being trained in pedagogical skills to ensure effective integration. Additionally,
we are leveraging a customized Learning Management System (LMS) to support teacherstudent interactions and CPD opportunities.
Vice Minister Karen:
Thank you, team Liberia. I appreciate your focus on addressing resistance and building teacher
confidence. It‚Äôs evident that your plans are well-aligned with your goals.
 Final Presentation - Transcription
Sarah/Alex:
Minister Karen, Caroline from Uganda has a question for Team Tanzania.
Caroline (Uganda):
Thank you. My question is about the practicality of communities of practice in a context where
there is a shortage of teachers. In Uganda, many teachers are responsible for teaching multiple
subjects in large classrooms. How does Tanzania address similar challenges in staffing and
timing for CoPs?
Alard (Tanzania):
Thank you, Caroline, for your question. We address teacher shortages by leveraging
technology to connect multiple schools. For example, one teacher can teach students across
three or four schools simultaneously through video conferencing tools like Zoom. This
approach is being piloted in two regions and has shown promising results.
For CoPs, we use hub schools and virtual platforms to facilitate teacher collaboration. Despite
staffing challenges, technology enables us to create spaces for knowledge sharing and
professional growth.
Vice Minister Karen:
Thank you, Tanzania. Nigeria has a follow-up question about the hierarchy and power
dynamics within CoPs. How do you address these issues?
Alard:
CoPs are designed to foster peer learning, where any member can take on the role of teacher
or learner. This dynamic reduces power imbalances and creates an environment where
everyone contributes and benefits.
Barbara (Expert):
Thank you, everyone. I want to emphasize the importance of scheduling these activities as part
of teachers‚Äô formal duties rather than extracurricular tasks. I‚Äôve heard excellent points today,
including the need for prioritization, piloting, and alignment with teaching and learning
objectives.
I also want to highlight the interconnectedness of these efforts. Incentives like certification can
motivate teachers, but they must be linked to practical, relevant training and resources. Let‚Äôs
continue focusing on people-centered strategies to ensure meaningful impact.

lessons.video_transcript:
Friday - Transcript
Sarah: Welcome, everyone, to this panel session. I‚Äôd like to give a quick logistic overview on how
to enable the interpretation channel. For those who need assistance with English, please click
on the interpretation icon located at the bottom left of your screen.
Karen (Vice minister): We‚Äôre going to begin, and I‚Äôll now give the floor to our Vice Minister. Thank
you, Sarah, and welcome, everyone, to this final day of our Policy Academy, which began on
Monday and will continue over the next two weeks. Today‚Äôs session marks the conclusion of our
panel series for this week. I‚Äôm honored to be with you in my role as Deputy Minister, joined by
our distinguished Minister Bob, who is also here with us. We sincerely thank each of you for
accepting our invitation to participate in this fourth panel.
This panel continues the discussions we began on Monday and will carry forward in the coming
weeks of the Policy Academy. The aim of today‚Äôs session is to discuss challenges and solutions
in promoting both distance learning and the open school model, which we envision as the school
of the future. We‚Äôre joined by representatives from various countries, including French and
English speakers, and invite all of you to feel comfortable participating in this exciting discussion.
Throughout the week, we have encountered numerous challenges, and our minister is keen for
us to find innovative solutions to address these issues in the months and years to come. We‚Äôll
begin with a brief introduction to the ‚Äúopen school‚Äù concept, which we sometimes refer to as
the ‚Äúschool of the future.‚Äù This concept is emerging as a response to the global shifts in
education caused by the pandemic. Today‚Äôs panel is well-represented by countries impacted by
these shifts, including the Sahel, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Senegal, Mali, and Togo.
The digital transformation in education raises critical questions and offers opportunities, and
today‚Äôs focus is to explore how distance learning and the concept of an open school can address
educational challenges on a societal level. One major issue, as we‚Äôve discussed since the
beginning of the week, is providing quality education to a vast number of young people while
ensuring inclusivity and equity.
We‚Äôll start by hearing from our colleagues in the DRC, Togo, and Mali on the topic of distance
learning. I‚Äôll begin with Thierry from the DRC. Thierry, why invest in distance learning, and what
problems is it designed to address?
Thank you very much, and thanks to everyone for all your contributions. I believe it's useful to
start by clearly distinguishing distance learning from open schools. These are complementary
concepts but operate independently. The need for distance education is not driven solely by
pandemics or health issues; it‚Äôs also a means of providing flexibility, especially to students at the
vocational or university level.
Take, for example, South Africa's UNISA, which has been offering distance education for many
years‚Äîeven before digital technology, using books and remote support. In distance education,
it‚Äôs crucial to define the audience and the problem being addressed. I always emphasize starting
with the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù before developing solutions. We recently conducted a valuable exercise with a
team in Senegal and the Sahel to understand school children‚Äôs circumstances and design tailored
solutions.
Research, including studies on massive open online courses (MOOCs), shows that self-directed
learning is challenging. Most learners, whether young or adult, struggle to complete courses
without structured support and deadlines. This highlights that distance education isn‚Äôt the same

as completely independent learning. It requires a support system, sometimes even more than
traditional school settings, to keep learners engaged and ensure they have a channel for clearing
doubts and working collaboratively.
Therefore, effective distance learning goes beyond technology‚Äîelectricity, connectivity, and
equipment must be in place, but support mechanisms are just as critical. Communication
channels between teachers and students help maintain engagement and address questions as
they arise. When designing distance learning from a pedagogical perspective, we aim to create
a supportive learning environment.
Ideally, stable electricity, good internet access, and affordable portable equipment are available,
but many regions lack these resources. Thus, we must find ways to use what is available, such
as community centers, local servers, or free Wi-Fi zones, where students can gather to
participate in distance learning. For instance, Kenya‚Äôs program addresses the shortage of quality
secondary-level teachers, especially in rural areas, by having top teachers in urban schools
deliver virtual lessons to rural schools.
This program, launched in 2022, includes around 190 schools and features a ‚Äúhub and spoke‚Äù
model where expert teachers broadcast lessons in subjects like mathematics and sciences to
nearby rural schools. However, the challenges in this project are largely human rather than
technological. Logistical aspects, such as coordinating schedules and exam dates, are critical to
the program‚Äôs success. Thus, distance learning requires careful logistical planning alongside
technological readiness.
On the topic of open schools, this model allows people to engage in learning experiences
without a rigid structure, making education accessible to all. Open schools emphasize inclusivity
and flexibility, providing opportunities for anyone to learn, regardless of their location or
background.
I‚Äôll now pass the floor to Mr. Mamadou from Mali, who has his hand raised.
Do you have anything to add? Are these the same steps you follow, or is there another approach
you take?
It's mostly the same steps. Let‚Äôs just remember that we began with defining the project
objectives. Starting with a clear project definition helped us set SMART objectives, which are
essential to the project's success. Afterward, we conducted a feasibility study, as my colleague
from Sael mentioned, involving all the educational departments of the Ministry of Education.
This study allowed us to understand the needs and aspirations of school dropouts, their current
occupations, and the ways we might meet their needs.
Following this, the next steps include data analysis, learner profiling, and stakeholder
engagement. We will also establish consensual standards, create educational pathways, set up
management systems, mobilize resources, and focus on the training of teachers and facilitators.
Emphasis on community mobilization is also crucial as we move towards launching the pilot
phase, which will be closely monitored for continuous improvement. This phase, once evaluated,
will lead to the project's extension and ensure its long-term sustainability. Thank you.
That‚Äôs excellent! I see that you have well-defined steps in place. I wonder where you currently
stand‚Äîwhat's the most pressing challenge you‚Äôre facing today? For instance, the Sahel project
is a multi-country initiative that likely has unique requirements and challenges.

In the Sahel countries involved in the relaunch project, a primary challenge is the lack of
infrastructure, which poses significant barriers to progress. There‚Äôs also resistance to change,
especially from teachers and parents, which complicates implementation. Another challenge is
the technological gap between urban and rural areas. Urban centers generally have connectivity,
but it's far more difficult to ensure this in rural areas, even though the open school model is
particularly relevant there, where it can reach our target population effectively.
Thank you, Mr. Bassirou. As for us, our main challenge has been gathering precise data on
specific needs. To address this, we conducted a study with support from a consultant and World

I agree; meeting deadlines and honoring our commitments are common themes across the

learning. I would like to invite Fred, our expert, who raised some points in the chat, to elaborate
on this distinction. Fred, the floor is yours.
Thank you. To clarify, distance learning means that the learning environment does not physically
bring students and teachers together. It can be through online courses, internet platforms, or
even YouTube. Traditional school models, however, have structured programs that guide
interactions with teachers and classmates and designate times for independent study.
In contrast, an open school model doesn‚Äôt necessarily require a fixed structure. ‚ÄúOpen‚Äù doesn‚Äôt
equate to distance learning. Rather, it means learners have more flexibility. For example, if I
need to focus on mathematics, I can engage solely in math lessons and receive recognition for
that specific learning, without simultaneously committing to French or other subjects. The open
model allows students to learn at their own pace, which can be essential for nomadic
communities or in situations where regular attendance is interrupted.
The flexibility of open schools allows for engagement and disengagement as needed. Distance
learning and self-directed learning can be part of an open model, but they are not mandatory.
The open model can also include in-person instruction. The key difference is that open schools
allow students to learn on their terms, attending classes when feasible and focusing on subjects
that align with their immediate needs.

questions, feel free to ask in the chat as we‚Äôll continue these discussions in the coming weeks.

Okay, thank you very much for being here for our second day of the Policy Academy. Yesterday,
we learned about the journey of four countries‚ÄîRwanda, Ethiopia, Tanzania, and Zimbabwe‚Äî
and their progress in developing EdTech policies, now gearing up for implementation. I think it
was a very interesting discussion. Today, we are going to dive into one of the pillars of EdTech
policies. These policies have various building blocks or pillars that need to be coordinated to
truly maximize technology‚Äôs potential in education. Today, our focus will be on infrastructure,
specifically connectivity to schools, students, and teachers, as well as the devices provided to
them for digital learning.
Just a reminder that the goal of this week's panel discussions is to present real-life examples of
how countries are tackling the challenges of designing and implementing EdTech policies. We
aim to learn as much from the successes as we do from the challenges and mistakes. I appreciate
the openness of our panelists for sharing both what went well and the lessons learned from the
obstacles they encountered. We want this Policy Academy to be a safe learning space for all
participating countries‚Äîa place where we can learn from each other and avoid repeating the
same mistakes.
Without further ado, I would like to invite Robert Hawkins, our Minister of the Republic of
Learning, to start today‚Äôs conversation on devices and connectivity. Our guests today include
representatives from Tanzania, Mr. Melchiory Baltazary; Zachary Muasya from Kenya; and Kofi
Adu-Manu from Ghana. Joining them is a group of experts, whom I am sure the Minister will call
upon for insights on how to best implement and tackle the significant challenges in providing
digital infrastructure for schools.
Thank you, Lucia. Today we have the United Republic of Learning assembled to address this
important challenge. It's rare to have such a meeting, and I‚Äôm gratified to see that 88 of our
colleagues from across the ministry are here to discuss connectivity, devices, and affordability,
ensuring access for our students. I realize there are many voices and viewpoints, so please use
the chat to share any questions you might have. I‚Äôll discuss these with three colleagues who have
brought briefs on their current digital infrastructure strategies within our Republic. I‚Äôm also
pleased to have three advisors here today, whom I will bring into the conversation as well.
Yesterday, our colleague Peter mentioned that our President has been pressing us since last
year‚Äôs meeting in Tanzania on how we will accommodate the growing number of young people
entering our education system over the next two decades. He continuously asks about our policy
and strategy for providing quality education services across the Republic. Today, that is our
challenge. My colleagues at the World Bank have suggested rethinking schools as transformative
spaces and extending education services to community centers and libraries.
With that in mind, I‚Äôll start with a few questions for our guests. First, I‚Äôd like each of you to briefly
describe the main connectivity challenge you face. Kofi, let‚Äôs begin with you‚Äîwhat would you
say is Ghana‚Äôs key challenge?
Thank you very much. The challenge in Ghana is reaching schools in hard-to-reach areas.
Great‚Äîreaching unconnected rural schools. Zachary, what about Kenya?

Thank you, Honorable Minister. The main challenge is to ensure inclusivity throughout the
process of implementing digital solutions in schools.
Thank you, Zachary. Inclusivity is essential. Melchiory, could you share Tanzania‚Äôs primary
challenge?
Certainly, Minister. For Tanzania, the challenges are primarily geographic‚Äîour country is vast‚Äî
and budgetary constraints.
We have identified several interrelated challenges: reaching unconnected areas, ensuring
inclusivity, and navigating geographical and budget constraints. This raises a critical question:
how do we prioritize our investments? Melchiory, can you share some strategies Tanzania is
considering to tackle these?
Thank you, Minister. Tanzania is currently implementing the Digital Tanzania Project to expand
connectivity nationwide. Additionally, we have a fund‚Äîthe Universal Communications Services
Access Fund‚Äîaimed at ensuring schools receive connectivity. We‚Äôre also collaborating with
major mobile network operators, such as Vodacom, Airtel, and Tigo, to extend connectivity.
Thank you, Melchiory. It‚Äôs encouraging to hear about the national connectivity efforts and
partnerships. Zachary, in Kenya, how are you ensuring that digital infrastructure reaches all
students, including those in remote areas?
In Kenya, the government is committed to improving connectivity through the Digital Literacy
Program. This program has partnered with telecommunications companies to extend internet
access to underserved areas, ensuring even remote schools receive connectivity. However, full
coverage has yet to be achieved due to various challenges.
Thank you, Zachary. And Kofi, how is Ghana addressing these infrastructure challenges?
Ghana‚Äôs Ministry of Education is running the School Connectivity Program, prioritizing rural and
underserved areas. They work with telecom providers to offer discounted services in these
areas, and they‚Äôre also implementing offline digital resources like the iBox. This device provides
secondary school content and supports e-learning for schools with limited connectivity.
Thank you for sharing these insights. Victor, a senior digital development specialist from the
World Bank, is with us today and has experience with connectivity projects. Victor, could you
provide some reflections on this discussion?
Thank you, Minister. An example from Kenya is mapping schools in relation to fiber
infrastructure. This helps prioritize which schools to connect first. Another challenge we
encounter is sustaining operational costs, as governments are often better at managing capital
expenses but struggle with ongoing costs.
Thank you, Victor. Melchiory, how does Tanzania plan to manage the long-term operational
costs of digital infrastructure?
Our approach includes incorporating connectivity costs into annual budgets, encouraging
sustainability beyond initial capital investments. We‚Äôre also collaborating with private
companies through corporate social responsibility and commercial agreements.

Thank you, Melchiory. Zachary, as we consider devices, what has Kenya learned about procuring
technology for schools?
In Kenya, we aim for a one-to-one device ratio, but device costs remain high. We're exploring
options like leasing and partnerships with tech companies to reduce expenses. We also
recognize the need for professional development so teachers can effectively use these devices.
Thank you, Zachary. The question of which device to prioritize remains: laptops, tablets, or
something else. Kofi, in Ghana, are you starting by prioritizing devices for teachers or students?
Ghana has launched a ‚ÄúOne Teacher, One Laptop‚Äù initiative where the government subsidizes
part of the laptop cost, with teachers covering the remaining amount through installments. This
has encouraged teachers to take ownership of their devices. Additionally, we are implementing
the Smart Schools Project, which aims to provide tablets to senior high school students.
Thank you, Kofi. The idea of device ownership by teachers seems effective. Neil, would you offer
some reflections on zero-rating data costs?
Certainly, Minister. Zero-rating data for educational websites can expand access to online
content without extra spending. It requires agreements with telecom providers and
consolidation of digital resources to a few main URLs, promoting easier access and more
disciplined content selection.
Thank you, Neil. Your points on simplicity, affordability, and political commitment are vital.
Today‚Äôs discussion has been rich, and I believe we are making progress. I want to remind
everyone that our goal is to develop a strategic action plan by the end of this Policy Academy.
In summary, today‚Äôs discussion emphasized the importance of defining a clear vision for digital
education. Infrastructure decisions must reflect pedagogical goals. Inclusivity, prioritizing
affordability, and recognizing the long-term costs of digital transformation were key points. Also,
collaborative efforts and partnerships will be essential to our success.
Thank you, Minister, and to all our participants. I look forward to seeing everyone at the same
time tomorrow as we continue these discussions.

the main objectives for this year: analyzing last year‚Äôs policies, sharing knowledge across
countries, and prioritizing specific gaps in EdTech implementation. A crosscutting theme for this
academy is the role of AI, which will be discussed in panels throughout the week.
During this week, we‚Äôll hold panel discussions where each country team can share lessons
learned, including challenges and successes, since the previous academy in spring 2023.
During week two, you‚Äôll engage in discussions with your country team, focusing on the next steps
and strategies for implementing the technology policy developed in previous iterations. Once
you complete work on your country teams‚Äô roadmap, there will be an opportunity to present in
a plenary session. Here, you‚Äôll share your presentations with other participating countries from
the EIC Policy Academy. We‚Äôll hold two sessions for this: one in English and one in French, with
links to be shared as we get closer to those dates.
Learning Hours and Certification Requirements
Across the three weeks, the estimated learning time ranges between 10 to 15 hours, with the
bulk of these hours during the week you meet with other countries for panel discussions. To be
eligible for certification, you are required to post at least one portfolio entry per week. We will
share more information about the platform later in this session, as Sarah will provide a
walkthrough.
Panel Schedule and Topics
For tomorrow's panel, the topic will be "Devices and Connectivity." On Wednesday, we will focus
on "Digital Skills and Digital Resources"; on Thursday, we‚Äôll discuss "EMIS and Implementation
Capacity"; and on Friday, there will be a special French session featuring Sahil Region countries
and discussions under the Open Schools initiative. All panels will be held at the same hour each
day, Tuesday through Friday.
Launch event -Transcript
Meeting Links and Logistics
To reduce confusion, we have not yet circulated the meeting links; however, in today‚Äôs meeting
link text, you‚Äôll find a link for tomorrow‚Äôs panel and links for the rest of the week. We‚Äôll also send
reminders, so please keep an eye out for updates. Feel free to ask any questions.
Opening Remarks and Inviting Dr. Lucia Deelo
I‚Äôll now hand it over to Dr. Lucia Deelo, who will lead a panel with representatives from countries
at the forefront of EdTech policy drafting. Lucia, over to you.
Lucia Deelo‚Äôs Introduction and Panel Purpose
Thank you, Shan. Good morning and afternoon to everyone. I am pleased to welcome you to
this session on the journey countries undertake to design and implement EdTech policies. Some
of today‚Äôs presenting countries began their journey following participation in last year‚Äôs Policy
Academy, and we expect this group to leave with a solid roadmap, motivated to advance EdTech
policies in their countries. The goal of this session is not only to highlight successes but to reflect
on challenges and lessons learned, as policymaking is complex and dynamic. We are grateful to
the countries willing to share insights and recommendations for others starting their EdTech
policy processes.
Country Presentations and Key Questions
We‚Äôve asked each presenter to introduce themselves, outline their position, and discuss:
Where they are in developing their EdTech policies.
The main steps undertaken.
Challenges faced during the process.
Recommendations for other countries starting this process.
Presentation by Bella Riamba, Rwanda
Thank you, Lucia. Hello, everyone; I‚Äôm Bella Riamba, Chief Digital Officer at the Ministry of
Education in Rwanda. My responsibilities include overseeing the digital transformation of the
education sector, policy drafting, and strategic planning. Here‚Äôs an outline of Rwanda‚Äôs EdTech
policy journey:
Policy Update: We realized the need to update our ICT Education Policy from 2016, given the
rapid evolution in technology. Rather than focusing solely on infrastructure, we broadened the
scope to include partnerships with the private sector and EdTech companies.
Launch event -Transcript
Support and Collaboration: With support from the World Bank and the Mastercard Foundation,
we formed an internal task force with members from various universities, agencies, and
ministries to draft the first framework. This ensured the inclusion of relevant stakeholders from
the outset.
Challenges and Recommendations: Time management was our main challenge. Policymaking
involves multiple stakeholders, and aligning their schedules can be difficult. My advice to other
countries is to finalize technical drafts quickly, allowing more time for stakeholder review and
approval. Engaging all stakeholders from the beginning accelerates the process, minimizes
revisions, and ensures smoother implementation.
Presentation by Alard Alex Barab, Tanzania
Thank you, Lucia. Good morning and afternoon. I‚Äôm Alard Alex Barab, Chairperson of Tanzania‚Äôs
task force for the National Digital Education Strategy (2024-2030). Here‚Äôs a summary of our
journey:
‚Ä¢ Situation Analysis: We conducted an analysis to assess current technology use across
schools, universities, and vocational colleges, resulting in a report highlighting the need
for a national digital education strategy.
‚Ä¢ Policy Context: We reviewed national, regional, and international policy frameworks,
including our e-Government Strategy and the African Union‚Äôs digital education strategy,
to align with ongoing digital transformation efforts.
‚Ä¢ Current Status: The strategy document is complete and has been approved by the
Ministry of Education management. After a national dialogue for stakeholder input in
June, we are now awaiting the official launch, expected soon.
‚Ä¢ Recommendations: Developing strategic frameworks early is essential as they guide the
implementation of digital education initiatives across the country.
The second recommendation is to have a highly inclusive team while developing this kind of
strategic document, so everyone can be included and represented in this exercise. Thank you
very much. Thank you, Cardo, for the insightful advice. Let‚Äôs move to Mulun from Ethiopia, who
has just developed a new EdTech policy. Mulun, could you share the lessons you‚Äôve learned and
your recommendations for other countries?
Thank you, Luia. Good morning, good afternoon everyone, and thank you to the organizers for
inviting me to share our experiences with our friends, countries, and governments. Our strategy
has been approved and is currently being implemented. The steps we went through involve
three main components: assessment, development, and evaluation and approval. We iterated
through these components using various approaches. First, we built a group of experts from
different stakeholders. The purpose of the assessment was to understand the local context and
determine what should be included in the strategy document.
As part of this, we assessed the local and regional policy frameworks, which provide general
guidance. These frameworks also inspired us to begin crafting a digital strategy policy document.
Key frameworks included the Ministry of UC training and education policy, which defines the
Launch event -Transcript
ministry‚Äôs mandate and authorities, helping us assess local challenges in the education sector
and how EdTech can contribute to addressing them. Other frameworks included Ethiopia‚Äôs
national digital strategy, Digital Ethiopia 2025, which prioritizes education as a sector for
national digital transformation, and the African Union regional framework, which we used as
foundational guidance to inform our policy.
We also examined global and local tech trends, as well as practices implemented by
development partners, neighboring developing economies, and developed countries. This
analysis helped us identify significant interventions and initiatives the government should
consider. In the development phase, our team developed the policy framework, with further
iterations between development, evaluation, and approval. The final strategy document was
approved by the Ministry of Education‚Äôs leadership and His Excellency, the minister.
During the evaluation phase, we used a variety of techniques. We organized small groups to
provide feedback on initial drafts, which we then refined based on their input. We also
conducted larger group workshops with stakeholders who might be impacted by the policy.
Development partners, including the World Bank, Mastercard Foundation, and UNICEF,
provided valuable feedback, aiding in the document‚Äôs development.
To address challenges faced during both pre- and post-development phases, I would make some
key recommendations. Firstly, focus on addressing large-scale educational challenges like
access, inclusion, diversity, and quality. A holistic approach is essential since many components
are interconnected; for example, technology availability requires user skills and data for
decision-making. Secondly, I recommend promoting open public goods, products, and services
that are developed incrementally, such as open content and open platforms. Use PL platforms,
prioritize a coordinated approach, and avoid siloed initiatives. Start small, focus on progressive
development, and set goals that push boundaries. Thank you, Lucia.
Thank you, Mulun, for sharing. Let‚Äôs now move to Jacob from Zimbabwe, who is currently
developing EdTech policies. Jacob, could you walk us through the steps you took and share your
recommendations for other countries?
Thank you, Lucia. Hello, everyone. I‚Äôm Jacob from Zimbabwe, and we‚Äôre currently in the process
of developing our EdTech policy. Our journey began in 2016 with World Bank assistance led by
Dr. Tom Cassidy. We developed a draft ICT policy for education. Our first step was to create a
technical working group, comprising members from the Department of ICT and e-learning, which
is responsible for implementing ICT across the Ministry of Primary and Secondary Education.
After forming the technical working group, we identified key representatives from other
departments within the ministry and relevant sister ministries, including Higher and Tertiary
Education, Finance, ICT, and Justice. Together, these formed a larger steering committee. We
began with consultations across schools nationwide, engaging stakeholders such as school
leaders, parents, communities, and even students. After collecting input, we classified the
findings under thematic areas, focusing on infrastructure, capacity building, change
management, and sustainability.
In 2016, despite finalizing our draft, we struggled to secure funding to advance the policy.
Additionally, political shifts within the country necessitated a policy review. Earlier this year,
with renewed assistance from the World Bank, we updated the 2016 draft to align with current
Launch event -Transcript
national frameworks like the National ICT Policy, the Broadband Plan, and a new heritage-based
curriculum, which emphasizes innovation. We are currently consolidating these updates and will
present them to senior management.
As for recommendations, I would emphasize starting early and adhering to timelines. We initially
planned consultations in August when teachers were on break, but delays pushed these to
September and October, conflicting with exam season. Also, align policies with significant
national events that may drive necessary adjustments. In our case, we align the policy with the
heritage-based curriculum‚Äôs seven-year cycle, which we review alongside the national ICT policy
every five years. Thank you, Lucia.
Thank you, Jacob, and to everyone for sharing your experiences. A common theme that emerges
is the importance of timing‚Äîboth technical and political considerations are essential to policy
development. Dedicate adequate time for consultations with stakeholders and political
negotiations to secure policy approval. Coordination across strategies and avoiding silos are
crucial to transforming these policies into actionable outcomes for education. We‚Äôll now
continue with other sessions, with a view toward learning from each other and advancing our
efforts to integrate technology in education.
Over to you, CH or Bob, to lead from here. Thank you to all our panelists.
Now, in this second phase, it‚Äôll be very exciting. I see some of them connected, but we were not
prepared to talk. If you allow me, Mr. Ahmed Bah, I‚Äôd like to give them the opportunity to share
a little bit. It‚Äôs a very dynamic team that continues to work closely together. We have very short
time; the president is calling me for another meeting soon, so we‚Äôll have to wind up here in
about 15 minutes.
Ahmed, it‚Äôs wonderful to see you again; our paths crossed many years ago. Please say a few
words, and then I would like to call on Yogesh afterwards to share his reflections. Ahmed, over
to you.
[Music]
Um, I‚Äôm going to give one minute to our colleague from Mauritius, Yogesh, to share a little bit
about data because we‚Äôve touched upon the open school, which we will go into more depth on
Friday. We‚Äôve talked about digital infrastructure, which Ms. Bah just mentioned, and we‚Äôve
touched briefly on digital skills, learning materials, and digital content. I want to hear more about
the challenges that you hope to address in the coming weeks regarding your data and systems.
I wonder if you can share some reflections from Mauritius.
Yes, thank you, honorable Minister. For us, our story is as follows: since 2017, we‚Äôve started a
new reform, and it was very important for us to provide technology to primary schools. We have
257 primary schools in Mauritius where children were provided with tablets to enhance learning
and use technology as leverage. You will understand that this required a lot of funding and also
significant internal capacity to digitalize the curriculum.
Our approach was more about partnership. We partnered with friendly countries like India and
revisited our local network with the Mauritius Institute of Education and the Mahatma Gandhi
Institute for Asian Languages, where we had a gargantuan task ahead of us to digitalize the
Launch event -Transcript
curriculum. As of now, Mauritius has been able to provide tablets to all its primary school
students.
We have also catered for continuity in pedagogy during temporary school closures by hosting a
range of pedagogical videos in the cloud. The national TV, MBC, airs these video programs when
schools are closed. We are also currently implementing an open educational resource policy that
touches on the primary, secondary, and tertiary subsectors. For the time being, we are busy
implementing Google Classroom, the fundamentals version, as the learning management
system.
This requires us to be very strategic in our actions. What we are discussing is a strategic
orientation map to implement a TEEX strategy, which will be a unifying document. We are talking
about six strategic objectives to implement and clarify the way ahead of us. I‚Äôll briefly outline
these strategic objectives:
1. Reimagining the role of technology in education, thinking about how AI can help us.
2. Engaging and empowering learning through technology, focusing on the learning side.
3. Teaching with technology.
4. Leadership: creating a culture and conditions for innovation and change.
5. Assessment: measuring for learning.
6. Infrastructure: enabling access and effective use of technology.
7. Accountability: setting up a robust database for policy decisions and analytics.
That‚Äôs what we are thinking ahead in terms of EdTech policy. Thank you, Yogesh. This is very
pertinent because these are the themes that are emerging in each of your policies and
strategies.
What we‚Äôll focus on in the next few weeks is supporting all of us to expand these policies, which
sometimes have to go to cabinet level, while the strategies that are more under our control, and
importantly, the action plan. We can‚Äôt do everything at once, and time is of the essence.
Again, I thank everybody for their reflections. As you know, I am not the best poet, and part of
the underlying theme of this event will be, as you all mentioned, reimagining education and the
important role that AI and new technologies are playing.
So, FEI, welcome from Ghana. I must admit that at the end of our last session, I took the synopsis
of the most important elements that came from each of your countries and asked my friend,
ChatGPT, to write a poem in the voice of Maya Angelou. This is what emerged: our beautiful
poem that we ended our policy academy show with. I shared a prompt with you in the chat so
that you can see how I was engaging with my assistant, whom I call Maya, to help me write my
poetry.
We will be learning more about AI as a cross-cutting theme all week. We‚Äôll have colleagues from
MasterCard Foundation, Microsoft, OpenAI, and hopefully Google DeepMind. I‚Äôm not sure if
they‚Äôre with us today, as well as a colleague from FCD, Sam, who will share perspectives on the
importance of AI.
Launch event -Transcript
What I want to do now is to model how we might approach hybrid learning in our own countries.
We will have these types of synchronous sessions, but I encourage all of you to learn and use
the learning platform that we‚Äôre utilizing in the United Republic of Learning to ensure that all of
us are sharing the best of our knowledge and ideas.
I‚Äôd like to pass over to my colleague Sarah, who will provide a brief overview of the platform
we‚Äôll be using over the next few weeks to share our experiences and delve deeper into
knowledge when we don‚Äôt have the opportunity to be face-to-face.
I must run soon, but I thank you all and want to assure you that time is of the essence. I‚Äôm not
sure how much longer I will be in this post, but I hope I will make it to three weeks for us to
finish this policy academy.
So over to you, Sarah, for conclusive words.
Thank you so much, Sarah. This is the end of the launch event. Tomorrow, please make sure to
connect at the same hour. We will circulate the meeting link again. Tomorrow, we‚Äôll talk about
Panel One, which focuses on devices and connectivity. We‚Äôve invited Tanzania, Kenya, and a
couple of other countries to share their experiences and challenges.
So be on the lookout for the invite, and we‚Äôll connect together again at the same time tomorrow
morning or afternoon based on your time zone.
So, talk to you all tomorrow. Thank you so much for your time. Talk to you tomorrow. Bye-bye!
[Various goodbyes]
Thank you, everyone. Bye-bye!

lessons.title: Lesson 4 : System management and implementation capacity Thursday
lessons.video_transcript:
Thursday - Transcript
Hello, and welcome back to our engaging discussions with the Minister of the United Republic
of Learning, where we‚Äôre exploring key EdTech policy topics. Today, we‚Äôll dive into three crucial
areas for implementing EdTech policies. We‚Äôve been strategizing around different pillars, and
now, we‚Äôre focusing on actionable steps and addressing some challenging issues necessary for
successful policy rollout.
The first topic we‚Äôll cover is costing‚Äîestimating the budget required to effectively implement
our planned activities and strategies. To turn our policies into reality, we need to understand
our resource requirements, encompassing human resources, technical capacity, and financial
investment. Policy development is about informed decision-making, setting priorities, and
knowing how much we‚Äôll need to make technology a reality in our schools. Our guest today,
alongside the Minister, will discuss the costs and strategies involved.
Our second topic centers on data. Data is essential not only for situation analysis in planning but
also for monitoring policy implementation. On day one, we discussed the importance of
infrastructure, such as tools for inventorying school resources, monitoring platform usage, and
tracking devices. Today, we‚Äôll explore how countries are leveraging educational management
information systems (EMIS) to generate data that enhances efficiency and guides resource
allocation toward innovation and technology.
Lastly, we‚Äôll discuss implementation capacity. EdTech policies demand coordination across
various domains, some beyond the Ministry of Education‚Äôs scope, like connectivity and digital
instructional material production. We‚Äôll explore how ministries can prepare to ensure effective
policy implementation, examining global models. Some countries have built robust EdTech
departments within their ministries, while others rely on dedicated agencies. Today, we‚Äôll hear
about CENDLOS (Centre For National Distance Learning and Open Schooling), a Ghanaian agency
collaborating with the Ministry of Education to implement EdTech policies comprehensively.
These discussions are vital, and I‚Äôm sure our Minister will pose challenging yet necessary
questions to ensure effective policymaking. Over to you, Minister, to begin today‚Äôs conversation.
________________________________________
Minister: Good morning, everyone! Following yesterday‚Äôs discussions on AI and its educational
role, I realized I need a language tutor myself, so I‚Äôve enlisted ChatGPT for some practice. I‚Äôm
working to make our United Republic of Learning more inclusive, given our linguistic diversity,
with over 2,000 languages spoken. This morning, I‚Äôll attempt a few phrases with the help of my
‚Äúlanguage tutor.‚Äù Thank you for your patience as I work on this skill!
Today, we‚Äôll focus on costs, data, and organization. But first, let‚Äôs hear from Mohyedine on
costing. Mohyedine, could you outline your thoughts on estimating the budget for our EdTech
strategies?
Mohyedine: Thank you, Minister. Good morning, everyone. Regarding costing, there‚Äôs often a
misconception that implementing EdTech means purchasing devices like computers or tablets.
Instead, we should focus on our objectives and select the most suitable tools accordingly. The
budgeting process is iterative; we revisit our categories‚Äîlike content development,
infrastructure, and training‚Äîto ensure they align with our goals.
 Thursday - Transcript
For our project in Sahel, we used the Open School of India as a cost benchmark, which offers
low-cost education at around $10‚Äì$15 per student. This gave us a reference point, although
each country‚Äôs context requires adjustments based on available resources like digital skills,
infrastructure, and connectivity.
Minister: Excellent points, Mohyedine. Let‚Äôs unpack this further. You highlighted the importance
of flexibility in selecting tools, identifying benchmarks like India‚Äôs Open School, and
differentiating capital and operational expenses. Given our funding challenges, can you
elaborate on these and share lessons from the Open School model?
Mohyedine: Certainly. India‚Äôs Open School model shows that scalable solutions don‚Äôt always
require traditional teachers. Facilitators or tutors can guide students through self-paced
learning. This differs from the conventional model‚Äîbuilding classrooms, hiring teachers‚Äîby
addressing scalability issues critical in resource-limited contexts. In India, digital skills are
widespread, while in sub-Saharan Africa, this remains a challenge, so adaptation is key.
Minister: Absolutely, the scalability of EdTech solutions is essential, especially with limited
budgets. Regarding operational versus capital costs, how do we manage future expenditures
sustainably?
Mohyedine: Learning platforms and digital content are fixed costs, scalable to reach many
students without extensive variable expenses. Devices for students are variable costs, which
grow with student numbers. The challenge is maximizing resources, so we should push variable
costs toward the fixed end where feasible. It‚Äôs a balance‚Äîensuring scalability while planning for
ongoing operational costs.
Minister: Thank you, Mohyedine. Let‚Äôs ensure everyone shares both costs and frameworks, so
we all gain insights across the United Republic of Learning.
"I think this is a very important point, and the work we're doing in the Sahel and surrounding
regions through the Open School initiative is creating political space for us to innovate and do
things differently. This initiative encourages us to think outside the box and to implement new
methodologies in service delivery to reach out-of-school youth. I urge all of us to seize this
opportunity to reimagine education for these youth by exploring novel approaches like the Open
School. Often, the political environment makes it difficult to challenge the status quo. While the
traditional approach may seem safe, I encourage us to take calculated risks and be innovative.
Without such efforts, we will never reach all the students who currently lack access to education,
let alone those within the system who are not learning effectively.
________________________________________
To truly improve learning outcomes, we need to ensure that students have more opportunities
each day to engage with knowledge, connect with others, think, learn, create, and innovate. A
critical part of this is having accurate data. It‚Äôs frustrating that our ministry manages multiple
data systems, with nearly 20 separate databases that don‚Äôt communicate with one another. We
have data in silos across different sectors‚Äîsuch as our social registry and various private
learning management systems‚Äîthat aren't integrated. As a result, we're not leveraging this
data in our daily decision-making processes.
 Thursday - Transcript
Mustapha, could you help us rethink our approach to organizing and utilizing our data systems?
How can we maximize their efficiency?
Thank you, Robert. Yes, I can hear you clearly. This is indeed a crucial question, especially in the
context of Nigeria, where we must consider both the data itself and its utility. In my 17 years of
experience in educational information management systems, I've seen that the essential data is
the kind that aids planning and supports service delivery mechanisms. It's also data that we can
analyze over time to identify trends and evaluate impact. Often, we collect data at various
stages‚Äîinitially for situation analysis and theory of change, midway for tracking progress, and
finally for impact evaluation. Each stage may require additional or different data that we hadn‚Äôt
initially anticipated. In Nigeria, for example, the institutionalization of data generation has been
a vital process since 2005, when the education management information system was
established. A robust data system requires clarity on data sources and stakeholder roles to
ensure accurate and actionable data.
Robert, are there key questions we should be asking our system to provide insights on?
Certainly. I would highlight three critical questions our system must address. First, is the data
collection aligned with our national education policy? Second, does the data give us insight into
teacher capacity and needs? Third, does our data framework align with both the national
educational management information system and the tech policy, particularly in infrastructure
and human development? These alignments ensure that our data supports both internal goals
and any external collaborations. Additionally, it's crucial to consider whether our data system
can identify where government resources should be directed, particularly for teacher
development.
Thank you, Mustapha. It‚Äôs often the case that we collect data without questioning the purpose.
I encourage everyone to think about the essential questions they need answered about our
system. For instance, do we have an accurate count of teachers in each school? Do we know the
credentials of these teachers, and how frequently do we need updates to make informed
decisions‚Äîmonthly, quarterly, or even daily?
________________________________________
Agatha, I‚Äôd like your input on what data countries should prioritize for collection. What‚Äôs
essential?
Certainly. When countries start collecting data, they need to focus on four areas. First, data
collection should align with national educational goals and policies. For example, if improving
digital literacy is a priority, then we must gather data on teacher and student access to devices.
Second, we need core educational metrics, such as student enrollment and teacher attendance,
along with data on teacher qualifications and workload. Third, infrastructure data is key‚Äî
knowing which schools have electricity or internet access is fundamental before introducing
digital tools. Lastly, equity and inclusion data is crucial. If inclusive education is a policy goal,
then our systems should track students with special needs.
Ultimately, I would argue that the primary purpose of collecting data is to understand student
learning outcomes. Any data on teachers, infrastructure, or resources should contribute to the
goal of effective student learning. One of the most significant points raised here is around
capacity. We need to ask ourselves: do we have the capacity? Often, we invest in a system that
 Thursday - Transcript
works for a while, but then the person managing it is recruited by the private sector‚Äî
sometimes even by companies like Microsoft. When that happens, the person who knows the
system leaves, and we revert to a paper-based approach, sending surveys to directors and
headmasters and collecting them manually. I walk around the ministry and see boxes of paper
surveys, which one dedicated staff member was entering into an Access database. A year later,
we publish our national census. This is not the way to run a ministry, so we need to address this
challenge seriously.
________________________________________
Nana, you‚Äôve been working with CENDLOS on innovative ways to leverage capacity to meet the
ministry's objectives, particularly regarding technology and innovation. Could you share your
experience and perspective?
Nana:
Good afternoon, everyone. I'm honored to be here to share our achievements at CENDLOS. I‚Äôm
speaking from Abuja, Nigeria, representing the Honorable Minister of Education. My name is
Nana Gyamfi Adwabour, Executive Director of CENDLOS, the Center for National Distance
Learning and Open Schooling, under Ghana's Ministry of Education. Our mandate is to make
education accessible to every child in Ghana, regardless of location, gender, or ability.
At CENDLOS, effective planning is key to managing EdTech. We developed the EdTech
Implementation Plan (EIP) framework for Ghana, focusing on human-centered design, equity,
accessibility, and quality. Transitioning from traditional to online education requires significant
attention to human development in the 21st century. Planning is crucial, from infrastructure to
training, to ensure a smooth transition without losing sight of human-centered design.
Minister:
Great. Nana, could you share one notable success and one major challenge encountered in
implementing this framework?
Nana:
Our biggest success has been training teachers for online teaching, which was challenging at
first, as many educators were resistant to digital tools. Through consistent training, however,
they have embraced this approach.
Our main challenge, or ‚Äúfailure,‚Äù was in initial attempts to implement the system without fully
involving teachers, particularly the "BBCs"‚Äîthose born before computers. Some of these
teachers are hesitant or even afraid to use digital tools, and while they possess valuable
experience, they often avoid EdTech resources. To address this, we‚Äôve adapted training to meet
them at their level, providing basic ICT instruction to make the transition easier.
Minister:
That‚Äôs crucial. Implementing change management to foster ownership is key. Thank you, Nana.
Fred, budget always comes up‚Äîwhat insights can you share?
 Thursday - Transcript
Fred:
Thank you. Around budgeting, there are four critical points. First, be realistic. UNICEF estimated
it would cost $1.4 trillion over 10 years to digitize low- and middle-income countries, about $50
per student annually. In Europe, it‚Äôs even higher at $500-$800 per student per year for mediumto high-range EdTech. Second, only invest in what you‚Äôll use; ineffective spending on unused
technology is widespread.
Third, improve procurement processes. Ministries should secure spare parts, adequate
equipment, and negotiate long-term licenses. Finally, maximize utilization. Many digital
resources remain underutilized due to fragmentation and limited usage promotion.
________________________________________
Minister:
Thank you, Fred. Lucia, could you offer some closing thoughts on implementation?
Lucia:
Certainly. Implementation capacity is key. While designing policies, it‚Äôs essential to consider the
human and financial resources needed for successful execution. Also, define the educational and
pedagogical model clearly, as this shapes costs and role assignments. An EdTech policy needs
champions within the ministry‚Äîpeople dedicated to overseeing implementation, supporting
schools, and ensuring the necessary technical expertise. Thank you all for a productive
discussion. Remember to complete the reflection activity on the platform, and we look forward
to tomorrow‚Äôs session.

Welcome to Week 2 of the 2024 Policy Academy!

This week, we transition from discussion to action as country teams work on designing their Roadmap to Action. colleagues.
